metadata.title: Kilowatts to Horsepower Converter
metadata.description: Convert kilowatts to mechanical horsepower with NIST- and ISO-aligned constants plus practical notes for motors, engines, lab gear, and appliances.

fields.label: Power in kilowatts (kW)
fields.help_text: Enter the rated kilowatts from the nameplate or calculation. Negative values are blocked.

introduction: Enter kilowatts to get the mechanical horsepower equivalent using the standard 1 kW = 1.34102209 hp factor.
Built for motors, engines, lab equipment, and even high-power kitchen gear where specs switch between kW and hp.
We keep the UI lean while reminding you that nameplates may list electrical input, not mechanical output.
methodology: Mechanical horsepower is treated as approximately 745.7 W; inverting gives 1 kW = 1.34102209 hp, the multiplier used here.
The factor aligns with NIST conversion tables and ISO 80000 power definitions; rounding is only for display.
If you need metric horsepower (PS/CV), multiply kW by about 1.36; this tool reports mechanical hp.
examples: 0.75 kW → 1.01 hp for a small lab stirrer or mixer.
2.2 kW → 2.95 hp for a common pump motor, often marketed as 3 hp.
10 kW → 13.41 hp to contextualize high-power appliances or light industrial drives.

faqs.question: Which horsepower definition is used?
faqs.answer: Mechanical horsepower (~745.7 W). If you need metric horsepower (PS/CV), multiply kW by roughly 1.36 instead.

faqs.question: Why might hp differ from the nameplate?
faqs.answer: Some nameplates list electrical input kW, not mechanical output. Efficiency, duty cycle, and test conditions affect rated hp even though the unit conversion is fixed.

faqs.question: How precise is the factor?
faqs.answer: Using 1.34102209 keeps reversibility with NIST/ISO constants. For typical sizing, 3–4 significant figures are sufficient; align rounding with your measurement uncertainty.

faqs.question: Can I convert back to kW?
faqs.answer: Yes—multiply hp by 0.745699872 (or divide by 1.34102209) to recover kilowatts, or use the companion hp-to-kW converter.

Highlights that nameplates may list input kW; hp output depends on efficiency and test conditions.
Supports everyday sizing while remaining consistent with NIST/ISO references.

glossary.definition: SI unit of power equal to 1000 watts, often used on motor and appliance nameplates.
Legacy power unit equal to roughly 745.7 watts of mechanical output at the shaft.
European variant of horsepower; 1 kW is about 1.36 PS, slightly above mechanical horsepower.
